title.narrative: Svenska Freds Byggande av varaktig fred i Myanmar 2014-18

description.narrative: Increased participation and influence of women, youth and ethnic minorities in local and regional peace processes in Myanmar. Feeding up to that main outcome are a number of bridging outcomes: 1. Women, youth and ethnic minorities from the target groups will have increased participation in local and regional peace processes. 2. One organisation in the project will have established a helpdesk office for conflict analyses, early warning and response systems, sharing best practices and lessons learned, conflict impact assessments, interfaith and diversity expertise. 3. Increased debate and acknowledgement in the Myanmar public domain and the international community, on women, youth and ethnic minorities' rights to have political influence in local, regional and national peace processes. 4. Civil society actors within the programme will contribute to preventing local and regional conflicts between four local groups in Chin state / Sagaing region.

Sida makes the assessment that the programme "Building sustainable peace in Myanmar" during the period 2014-2017, presented on behalf of the Swedish Peace- and Arbitration Society, SPAS, is highly relevant in relation to the Swedish Results Strategy for international developement cooperation in Myanmar 2013-2017. The overall objective of the programme is aligned to the results area of "Broad popular partcipation in the peace process" and the specific result to gain "Increased participation of women and ethnic minorities in the peace process."
The programme will be implemented by SPAS and the umbrella organisation AYO SDA in Myanmar in cooperation with eight local, community based organisations. The activities will consist of seminars, awareness-raising initiatives and advocacy work related to peace building and will be realised in 14 of the most conflict-affected areas in the country.

Svenska Freds- och Skiljedomsföreningen kommer att under perioden 2014-2017 att genomföra programmet "Byggande av varaktig fred i Myanmar". Den övergripande målsättningen med programmet är att bidra till kvinnors, ungas och etniska minoriteters ökade delaktighet och påverkan i de lokala, regionala och nationella fredsprocesserna i landet. Programmet präglas av en fredsbyggande ansats med ett lokalt, gräsrotsperspektiv i grunden. Programmet har utformats och kommer att genomföras i nära samverkan med paraplyorganisationen Ar Yone Oo Social Development Association, AYO SDA, och åtta organisationer med varierande profil inom fred- och konfliktfrågor, mänskliga rättigheter, ickevåld, kvinnor och urfolks rättigheter, rättvist naturresursutnyttjande. Aktiviteter planeras i 14 av de mest konfliktdrabbade regionerna i Myanmar. Initiativet innebär bland annat seminarier, kapacitetsutvecklande insatser samt påverkansarbete riktat mot politiker och policyfunktioner.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The final report states that programme activities have been implemented in 151 cities, towns and villages i 13 states and regions. Through SPAS'nine partner organisations, the programme has organized over 200 official advocacy meetings and round table discussions with more than 600 policymakers / stakeholders and an even higher humber of unofficial meetings recorded reaching another 900 policymakers and stakeholders. SPAS reports that partner organisation. Over 700 trainings have been conducted reaching altogether 22 860 people. This is not counting public awareness raising events and reports that have been published and disseminated. During the programme life-span, partners have developed or joined initiatives linked to the peace process in different ways, as noted also in the external evaluation in 2017. In Chin State AYO (SPAS' main partner) has facilitated the establishment and organising of the first officially recognized state level CSO Forum in the peace process. Other partners have participated in CSO fora in other parts of the country. Individual participants in the programme's trainings and workshops have participated in peace process events and entities such as the Joint Monitoring Commission at state level. Although not highlighted in the summarised final report, AYO involvement in relation to the peace process extended further than the CSO Forums to include helping to organise the Chin National Political Dialogue Conference with participation by CSOs, political parties as well as Ethnic Armed Organisation representatives and a few representatives from the Chin state government and parliament and the military. The director of AYO became a member of the Chin National Dialogue Joint Committee and participated in drafting the Chin National Dialogue Resolution that was handed over to the Union Peace and Dialogue Joint committee and presented at the Union Peace Conference in 2017. The programme has also included components that could be categorized as work to support intercommunal harmony. An interesting example is work done by partners along Myanmar's Western border with Kuki and Thadou women's groups, youth groups and in multi-stakeholder yearly forums drawing in 120 - 150 participants from 8 - 10 ethnic groups in the area. Trainings, seminars and workshops have been organised on subjects ranging from local, regional and national peace processes, ceasefire agreements, civilian ceasefire monitoring, political dialogue, civil society, youth and women’s participation in the peace process, gender equality, women’s empowerment, as well as local and regional development and security issues. SPAS' main partner, AYO, has continuously supported the Chin CSO Network and has, together with another partner in the programme, been closely involved in the 18 month process of drafting a National Youth Policy which was launched and endorsed by the State Counsellor in January 2018.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
